head.title: Poly(terphenylene) Anion Exchange Membranes: The Effect of Backbone Structure on Morphology and Membrane Property | ACS Macro Letters

meta.content: Poly(terphenylene) Anion Exchange Membranes: The Effect of Backbone Structure on Morphology and Membrane Property

A new design concept for ion-conducting polymers in anion exchange membranes (AEMs) fuel cells is proposed based on structural studies and conformational analysis of polymers and their effect on the properties of AEMs. Thermally, chemically, and mechanically stable terphenyl-based polymers with pendant quaternary ammonium alkyl groups were synthesized to investigate the effect of varying the arrangement of the polymer backbone and cation-tethered alkyl chains. The results demonstrate that the microstructure and morphology of these polymeric membranes significantly influence ion conductivity and fuel cell performance. The results of this study provide new insights that will guide the molecular design of polymer electrolyte materials to improve fuel cell performance.

div.p: A new design concept for ion-conducting polymers in anion exchange membranes (AEMs) fuel cells is proposed based on structural studies and conformational analysis of polymers and their effect on the properties of AEMs. Thermally, chemically, and mechanically stable terphenyl-based polymers with pendant quaternary ammonium alkyl groups were synthesized to investigate the effect of varying the arrangement of the polymer backbone and cation-tethered alkyl chains. The results demonstrate that the microstructure and morphology of these polymeric membranes significantly influence ion conductivity and fuel cell performance. The results of this study provide new insights that will guide the molecular design of polymer electrolyte materials to improve fuel cell performance.

Fuel cells are among the most promising candidate technologies for addressing the impending energy crisis. Anion exchange membrane (AEM) fuel cells have significant advantages over proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells, including faster kinetics of oxygen reduction reaction and the capacity to use nonprecious metal catalysts (e.g., silver, cobalt, nickel).
(1)
However, the development of commercially viable AEM fuel cells remains challenging because of the lack of highly conductive, durable AEMs under basic operating conditions. First, hydroxide conductivity in AEM fuel cells is generally lower than proton conductivity in PEM fuel cells because of the inherently lower mobility of hydroxide ions and the insufficient dissociation of hydroxide ions from the anion conductive group.
(2)
Second, compared to perfluorosulfonated ionomer in PEMs, most aromatic AEMs have less developed ion channels in microstructure, which tends to retard ion transport.
(3)
Third, most aroamtic AEM materials prepared by condensation polymers contain aryl ether bonds in their backbone, thus, they cannot survive in the most desirable AEM fuel cell operating environment (i.e., highly alkaline conditions above 80 Â°C) in which strongly basic hydroxide ions are abundant.
(4)
These limitations of AEMs are key bottlenecks in the development of high-performance AEM fuel cells.

Numerous strategies have been used to improve hydroxide conductivity and thermochemical stability of AEMs. These strategies can be classified into two main types: (a) the synthesis of new anion conductive groups, and (b) the design of new polymer architectures.
(5)
To date, various ion conductive moieties have been investigated as new tethered ionic groups to replace conventional quaternary ammonium (QA) in AEMs.
(2)
However, when all relevant factors including hydroxide conductivity, alkaline stability, and synthetic versatility are considered, QA moieties remain as the most widely used hydroxide-conducting headgroup for AEMs.

Designing a new polymer architecure for AEMs to improve ion conductivity is a complicated task because it requires profound understanding of the mechanisms of ion transport and their relationship to polymer structure. Various PEMs with flexible tethered side chains and comb-shaped polymer architectures (e.g., Nafion) have been synthesized to enhance the degree of microphase separation in morphology. These materials have demonstrated superior proton conductivity compared with that of their analogues in which sulfonic acid groups are attached directly along the rigid aromatic chains.
(6)
QA groups on AEMs are ordinarily prepared via halomethylation followed by quaternization, which produces AEMs with QA groups closely attached to the aromatic polymer backbones. These AEMs tend to give poor alkaline stability (particularly above 80 Â°C), because the presence of a positively charged nitrogen cation at the activated benzylic position promotes nucleophilic attack of hydroxide anions. The close proximity of the QA group to the polymer backbone also induces high swelling of the membrane and less-ordered, phase-separated morphologies, which result in low hydroxide conductivity.

Recently, long flexible side chains terminated by QA groups have been used to facilitate the formation of microphase-separated morphology in AEMs.
(7)
Our group also reported high-molecular-weight, solvent-processable AEMs based on poly(biphenyl alkylene)s (BPN1-
m

(7b)
Compared with other AEM materials prepared from typical base-catalyzed condensation polymers, these aryl ether-free aromatic AEMs exhibit superior chemical and mechanical stabilities. Although additional study is needed, we believe that the incorporation of QA at the end of long alkyl chains in aromatic polymers improves the mobility of hydroxide ion. When the morphology of these BPN1 membranes was examined with small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS), however, no obvious scattering peak was observed.

While investigating membrane properties of different backbone structures, we discovered that a proper arrangement of polymer backbone is beneficial in creation of ion-conductive polyelectrolyte membrane morphology with enhanced hydroxide ion conductivity. Thus, we herein report the results of our study of the influence of backbone structure of anion-conducting polymers on morphology and the overall performance of AEMs. We synthesized terphenyl-based hydroxide ion-conducting polymers using either
para
-terphenyl (
p
-TPN1) or
meta
-terphenyl (
m
-TPN1) as an aromatic monomer (see
Figure 1
). When biphenyl was used as an aryl monomer,
(7b)
because the acid-catalyzed polycondensation is highly regioselective only for 4- and 4â²-positions,
(8)
the resulting BPN1 polymers did not allow further structural variations in the polymer backbone. However, the use of two different terphenyl monomers may demonstrate how changing the orientation of the backbone influences the properties of these side chain-functionalized polymers;
p
-TPN1 and
m
-TPN1 have the same concentration of ionic side chains and differ only in the substitution of the middle aromatic ring (
para
vs
meta
). To investigate the effect of changes in polymer backbone structure, we analyzed the physical and morphological properties of these two terphenyl polymers and compared them with a biphenyl polymer (i.e., BPN1-65) with a similar ion exchange capacity (IEC). Our results provide new insights for the design of high-performance anion-conducting polymers.

Bromoalkyl-tethered precursor polymers (
p
-TPBr and
m
-TPBr) were synthesized via one-pot, acid-catalyzed FriedelâCrafts polycondensation (
Scheme S1, Figure S1
). The bromopentyl group on the side chain of these precursor polymers was subsequently converted to trimethylpentylammonium bromide via a substitution reaction with trimethylamine, affording
p
-TPN1 and
m
-TPN1. The weight-average molecular weights (
M
w
) of
p

m
-TPBr were determined with gel permeation chromatography (
Table 1
). The molecular weight of
p
-TPBr is lower than that of
m
-TPBr, likely because the former has lower solubility owing to the more rigid
para
-terphenyl moieties. Compared with the terphenyl polymers, biphenyl-based BPBr-65 had a higher molecular weight owing to the smaller and less rigid biphenyl in the repeating unit and better solubility.

). Comparison of the integral ratio of trimethylammonium protons at 3.02 ppm and aromatic proton peaks at 7.30â7.80 ppm indicated that the quaternization reaction gave quantitative conversion. IECs calculated from the relative intensity of the repeating units were 2.12 and 2.15 mequiv/g for

The thermal stability, chemical stability under alkaline conditions, and mechanical durability of the membranes fabricated from these polymers were evaluated for practical applications in fuel cells. Both
p
-TPN1 and
m
-TPN1 showed good thermal stability up to 250 Â°C, at which the QA group started to decompose, as shown with TGA (
Figure S3
). Chemical stability testing of these membranes in an alkaline environment was conducted in 1 M NaOH at 80 Â°C, and experimental IECs were measured with back-titration and
1
H NMR spectra after 30 days of treatment (
Table S1 and Figure S4
). Similar to the results of a previous study of BPN1 polymer,
(7b)
the differences in IEC values and
1
H NMR spectra of terphenyl ionic polymers were negligible, indicating excellent long-term thermochemical stability. Even after treatment in 1 M NaOH at 95 Â°C for 30 days, the decrease in IEC was negligible (
Table 2
). We conclude that a polymer design based on a flexible alkyl chain-tethered QA headgroup and aryl ether-free bonds on backbone is a key to the excellent alkaline stability of these aromatic AEMs. When the mechanical properties were examined under conditions of 50 Â°C with 50% relative humidity, the terphenyl polymers had elongations at break that were lower than that of BPN1-65 because their additional aromatic ring along the polymer backbone structure makes them less flexible than their biphenyl counterpart (
Figure S5
). Compared with
p
-TPN1,
m
-TPN1 showed greater stress and elongation at break owing to a combination of a more flexible backbone and higher molecular weight.

The development of ionic clusters via nanoscale phase separation of hydrophobicâhydrophilic domains helps to facilitate ion transport in fuel cell membranes.
(5b, 5d)
The microstructure of membranes was examined with small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS). As shown in
Figure 2
, biphenyl polymer BPN1-65 showed no scattering peak in the SAXS spectrum. However,
Figure 2
a shows large-width scattering peaks at 0.96 and 1.2 nm
â1
corresponding to
d
-spacing of approximately 6.5 and 5.0 nm, respectively, for the
m
-TPN1 membrane. By contrast, those two peaks appeared with very low intensities in the
p
-TPN1 membrane, indicating that the level of microphase separation for this polymer is insignificant. The difference in their morphologies arose from the different connectivity of repeating units. A 3D model structure study suggests that
meta
-connectivity of terphenyl units allows the polymer chains to fold back to maximize the interaction between hydrocarbon backbones and promote the peripheral formation of ion aggregates, similar to the case of rigid
meta
-substituted foldamers,
(9)
while the backbone chains of
para
-terphenyl tend to spread out to prevent such conformation (
Figure 3
). The difference in morphological behavior of these two terphenyl membranes is also evidenced in TEM images in which
m
-TPN1 membrane sample stained with tetrachloroplatinate ions shows greater contrast indicating more obvious hydrophobicâhydrophilic phase separation (
Figure 2
c,d).

Figure 2. (a) SAXS and (b) WAXS data of ionic polymers and TEM images of (c)
p
-TPN1 and (d)
m
-TPN1.

Figure 3. 3D model structure of the ionic polymers. (a)
p
-TPN1 (10 repeating units), (b)
p
-TPN1 (48 repeating units), (c)
m
-TPN1 (10 repeating units), and (d)
m
-TPN1 (48 repeating units). Color code: white for hydrogen, gray for carbon, red for nitrogen, blue for fluorine.

The effect of terphenyl arrangement on the polymer chain packing was further examined by wide-angle X-ray scattering (WAXS;
Figure 2
b). While there is no obvious peak observed in WAXS for
p
-TPN1,
m
-TPN1 showed a strong peak at 2Î¸ angle of 8.35Â°, corresponding to interchain spacing of 10.6 Ã . This spacing is believed to correlate with the intermolecular distance between the self-assembled polymer structures, as graphically illustrated in
Figure S6
. A similar regular arrangement of side chains has been frequently observed for planar conjugated polymer systems.
(10)
It is likely that the presence of additional kinked structure from
meta
-substituted polymer could contribute the polymer chains to fold back and allow to form more compact polymer structure and promote self-assembly of ionic side chains. Therefore, we concluded that the difference in the backbone structure (
para
- vs
meta
-terphenyl) has influenced the self-assembly of polymer chains, which further affects the ion conductivity and morphology of the polymer membranes.

The anion conductivities of these polymers were measured with a four-point probe method. The chloride and hydroxide ion conductivities of the
p
-TPN1 and
m
-TPN1 membranes both increased as temperature rose from 30 to 80 Â°C (
Tables 2
and
S2
, and
Figure 4
b). At room temperature,
p
-TPN1 and
m
-TPN1 exhibited hydroxide ion conductivities of 43 mS/cm and 54 mS/cm, respectively. Hydroxide conductivity steadily increased with temperature and reached 81 mS/cm for
p
-TPN1 and 112 mS/cm for
m
-TPN1 at 80 Â°C owing to increased water absorption and the enhanced mobility of ion and water molecules. The hydroxide conductivity of
p
-TPN1 is close to that of BPN1-65 (88 mS/cm), although the water uptake of the
p
-terphenyl polymer is much lower than that of the biphenyl polymer (65% vs 85% in OH
â
form; see
Table 2
). Although the two terphenyl-based AEMs have similar IEC values (2.12â2.15 mequiv/g),
m
-TPN1 has much higher hydroxide ion conductivity. The hydroxide conductivity of
m
-TPN1 nearly reaches that of BPN1â100 (122 mS/cm), which has much higher IEC (2.70 mequiv/g) and hydration number (Î» = 26), demonstrating more favorable morphology for hydroxide ion transportation. As indicated by the morphology data in
Figure 2
, unlike BPN1-65 and
p
-TPN1, which show no or less ordered morphology, the higher ion conductivity of
m
-TPN1 can be attributed to better formation of ionic clusters by self-assembly of hydrophobic polymer backbone and ion-tethered side chains.
Figure 4. (a) Hydration number (in hydroxide ion form) and (b) hydroxide conductivity of ionic polymers as a function of temperature.

Figure S7
shows the fuel cell performance of
p
-TPN1 and
m
-TPN1 as AEMs at 80 Â°C. The open-circuit voltage was 1.01 V, which is close to the theoretical value in hydrogen-supplied fuel cells. The maximum power density obtained from cells using
m
-TPN1 was 196 mW cm
â2
at a current density of 358 mA cm
â2
. This power density was higher than that achieved with
p
-TPN1 (154 mW cm
â2
at a current density of 309 mA cm
â2
) under the same conditions despite the similarity in IEC values of the polymers. The higher power density from
m
-TPN1 may be attributable to the (a) greater hydroxide conductivity derived from the ordered morphology structure and (b) higher molecular weight of the polymer, which may help to build a more effective three-phase boundary in the catalyst layer. Membrane electrode assemblies using the
meta
-terphenyl membrane also showed low high-frequency resistance (HFR; <0.2 Î© cm
2
), which contributes to high fuel cell performance. Although components used for membrane electrode assembly (MEA) were not optimized for fuel cell tests, these test results of
m
-TPN1 clearly demonstrate excellent thermochemical stability and fuel cell performance at 80 Â°C. Better optimized MEAs with different combinations of ionomer and electrocatalysts will improve fuel cell performance further. Given the results of our study of structureâproperty relationships, we conclude that the hydrophobicity and geometry of polymer backbones play an important role in creating microstructure that helps facilitate ion transport and improve the performance of AEMs in fuel cells. Our discovery suggests a new strategy for molecular design to further improve the performance of future-generation polymer electrolyte materials.

In this review, we examine the most recent progress and research trends in the area of alk. polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) development in terms of material selection, synthesis, characterization, and theor. approach, as well as their fabrication into alk. PEM-based membrane electrode assemblies (MEAs) and the corresponding performance/durability in alk. polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs). Resp. advantages and challenges are also reviewed. To overcome challenges hindering alk. PEM technol. advancement and commercialization, several research directions are then proposed.

Page, Oliver M. M.; Poynton, Simon D.; Murphy, Sam; Ong, Ai Lien; Hillman, Donna M.; Hancock, Cathryn A.; Hale, Michael G.; Apperley, David C.; Varcoe, John R.

Radiation-grafted anion-exchange membranes (AEM) contg. pendent benzyltrimethylammonium, 1-benzyl-3-methylimidazolium and 1-benzyl-2,3-dimethylimidazolium functional head-groups were synthesized with ion-exchange capacities in the range 1.7-1.9 meq g-1. The ionic conductivities of the AEMs were also comparable (24.5 Â± 1.8 mS cm-1 at 50 Â°C). The alkali stability (in aq. potassium hydroxide (1 mol dm-3) at 60 Â°C) of the 1-benzyl-2,3-dimethylimidazolium head-groups was superior to the 1-benzyl-3-methylimidazolium but inferior to the benzyltrimethylammonium benchmark head-groups. Radiation-grafted AEMs contg. pendent 1-benzyl-2,3-dimethylimidazolium head-groups are not suitable for application in electrochem. devices contg. highly alk. environments.

A tetrakis(dialkylamino)phosphonium cation was evaluated as a functional group for alk. anion exchange membranes (AAEMs). The base stability of [P(N(Me)Cy)4]+ was directly compared to that of [BnNMe3]+ in 1 M NaOD/CD3OD. The high base stability of [P(N(Me)Cy)4]+ relative to [BnNMe3]+ inspired the prepn. of AAEM materials composed of phosphonium units attached to polyethylene. The AAEMs (hydroxide cond. of 22 Â± 1 mS cm-1 at 22 Â°C) were prepd. using ring-opening metathesis polymn., and their stabilities were evaluated in 15 M KOH at 22 Â°C and in 1 M KOH at 80 Â°C.

A novel hydroxide-conductive ionomer, tris(2,4,6-trimethoxyphenyl)polysulfone-methylene quaternary phosphonium hydroxide (TPQPOH), has been synthesized. TPQPOH has excellent soly. in some low-boiling-point solvents, high hydroxide cond., and outstanding alk. stability. The H2/O2 hydroxide exchange membrane fuel cells contg. the TPQPOH ionomer exhibits a significant increase of peak power d. and redn. of internal resistance.

Anion exchange membranes (AEMs) find widespread applications as an electrolyte and/or electrode binder in fuel cells, electrodialysis stacks, flow and metal-air batteries, and electrolyzers. AEMs exhibit poor stability in alk. media; their degrdn. is induced by the hydroxide ion, a potent nucleophile. We have used 2D NMR techniques to investigate polymer backbone stability (as opposed to cation stability) of the AEM in alk. media. We report the mechanism behind a peculiar, often-obsd. phenomenon, wherein a demonstrably stable polysulfone backbone degrades rapidly in alk. solns. upon derivatization with alk. stable fixed cation groups. Using COSY and heteronuclear multiple quantum correlation spectroscopy (2D NMR), we unequivocally demonstrate that the added cation group triggers degrdn. of the polymer backbone in alk. via quaternary carbon hydrolysis and ether hydrolysis, leading to rapid failure. This finding challenges the existing perception that having a stable cation moiety is sufficient to yield a stable AEM and emphasizes the importance of the often ignored issue of backbone stability.

FTIR anal. indicated the cleavage of aryl-ether linkages in quaternized PAEs under high pH environments, while no backbone degrdn. in quaternized poly(phenylene) was obsd. The backbone degrdn. of PAEs not only significantly reduced the mech. properties of the membranes, but also neg. impacted hydroxide cond. Membrane electrode assemblies using both PAE and poly(phenylene) membranes showed good initial alk. membrane fuel cell performance. However, the PAE membrane electrode assembly displayed larger performance losses and failure after only 55 h, due to a mech. breach. No catastrophic failure of the poly(phenylene) membrane electrode assembly occurred after 300 h, which further confirmed the stability of the polymer backbone.

Anion exchange membranes are an important component in alk. electrochem. energy conversion and storage devices, and their alk. stability plays a crucial role for the long-term use of these devices. Herein, a systematic study was conducted for the anal. of polymer backbone chem. stability in alk. media. Nine representative polymer structures including poly(arylene ether)s, poly(biphenyl alkylene)s, and polystyrene block copolymers were studied for their alk. stability. Polymers with aryl ether bonds in their repeating unit showed poor chem. stability when treated with KOH and NaOCH3 solns., whereas polymers without aryl ether bonds [e.g., poly(biphenyl alkylene)s and polystyrene block copolymers] remained stable. Addnl. NMR studies and d. functional theory (DFT) calcns. of small mol. model compds. that mimic the chem. structures of poly(arylene ether)s confirmed that electron-withdrawing groups near to the aryl ether bonds in the repeating unit accelerate chem. degrdn. Results from this study suggest that the use of all-carbon-based polymer repeating units (i.e., polymers not bearing aryl ether bonds) can enhance long-term alk. stability of anion exchange membranes in electrochem. energy devices.

Alk. polymer electrolytes (APEs) are an emerging material that enables the use of nonprecious-metal catalysts in electrochem. energy technol., such as fuel cell and water electrolysis. Yet the OH- conduction in APE has been of much lower efficiency than the H+ conduction in its acidic counterpart (typically Nafion), leading to a large dissipative loss in energy conversion applications. Here we report that, by properly constructing ion-aggregating structures in APE, a OH- conducting highway can be built, such that the OH- conduction in APE becomes as efficient as the H+ conduction in Nafion (greater than 0.1 S cm-1 at 80 Â°C under moderate ion-exchange capacity 1.0 mmol g-1). The optimal approach to constructing such an ionic highway is first screened computationally using coarse-grained mol. dynamics (CGMD) simulations, and then implemented exptl. based on a quaternary ammonia polysulfone (QAPS) model system. The resulting ordered structure of ion assembly has been unambiguously revealed by both the theor. calcd. structure factor and exptl. results of TEM and SAXS. These findings have not only furthered our understanding about the ionic channels in APE, but also provided a general strategy for the rational design of polymer electrolytes.

The polymers were sol. in DMF, and DMSO at room temp. and methanol at 40 Â°C while remaining insol. in water. The polymeric membranes were transparent and flexible and exhibited hydroxide ion conductivities above 100 mS/cm at 80 Â°C. The results of 1H NMR and titrn. measurements demonstrated an excellent chem. stability of the synthesized polyfluorene, even after treatment in 1 M NaOH soln. at 80 Â°C for 30 days. The results of this study suggest a feasible approach to the synthesis and practical applications of a new class of alk. anion exchange membranes.

span.span: Precision Synthesis of Narrow Polydispersity, Ultrahigh Molecular Weight Linear Aromatic Polymers by A2 + B2 Nonstoichiometric Step-Selective Polymerization

Precision Synthesis of Narrow Polydispersity, Ultrahigh Molecular Weight Linear Aromatic Polymers by A2 + B2 Nonstoichiometric Step-Selective Polymerization
Cruz, Alfredo R.; Hernandez, M. Carmen G.; Guzman-Gutierrez, Maria T.; Zolotukhin, Mikhail G.; Fomine, Sergei; Morales, Salvador L.; Kricheldorf, Hans; Wilks, Edward S.; Cardenas, Jorge; Salmon, Manuel
Macromolecules (Washington, DC, United States)
(
2012
),
45
(
17
),
6774-6780
CODEN:
MAMOBX
; ISSN:
0024-9297
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
A reliable and practical approach is offered for the two crit. fundamental challenges that remain in step-growth polymn.: synthesis of narrow polydispersity and ultrahigh mol. wt. polymers. The polymers are obtained by superacid catalyzed polyhydroxyalkylation involving two consecutive steps - slow and fast. Polymer syntheses with decrease in reactivity of intermediates lead to narrow polydispersity polymers, while nonstoichiometric reactions result in polymers of high and ultrahigh mol. wt. Linear arom. polymers with ultra high mol. wt. Mn > 1 000 000 and narrow polydispersity (Mw/Mn = 1.15-1.16) have been obtained. An unusual step-selective mechanism is suggested for the formation of these polymers.

(
American Chemical Society
)
A review that surveyed the field of foldamers-the study of conformational in synthetic chain mols. The products of this field are new oligomeric backbones that adopt a particular type of secondary structure through noncovalent interactions. When one looks deeper into the chem. details making up these secondary structures, what emerges to date is that only a relatively small no. of "good folders" have as of yet been identified.

In this review, we examine the most recent progress and research trends in the area of alk. polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) development in terms of material selection, synthesis, characterization, and theor. approach, as well as their fabrication into alk. PEM-based membrane electrode assemblies (MEAs) and the corresponding performance/durability in alk. polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs). Resp. advantages and challenges are also reviewed. To overcome challenges hindering alk. PEM technol. advancement and commercialization, several research directions are then proposed.

Radiation-grafted anion-exchange membranes (AEM) contg. pendent benzyltrimethylammonium, 1-benzyl-3-methylimidazolium and 1-benzyl-2,3-dimethylimidazolium functional head-groups were synthesized with ion-exchange capacities in the range 1.7-1.9 meq g-1. The ionic conductivities of the AEMs were also comparable (24.5 Â± 1.8 mS cm-1 at 50 Â°C). The alkali stability (in aq. potassium hydroxide (1 mol dm-3) at 60 Â°C) of the 1-benzyl-2,3-dimethylimidazolium head-groups was superior to the 1-benzyl-3-methylimidazolium but inferior to the benzyltrimethylammonium benchmark head-groups. Radiation-grafted AEMs contg. pendent 1-benzyl-2,3-dimethylimidazolium head-groups are not suitable for application in electrochem. devices contg. highly alk. environments.

The base stability of [P(N(Me)Cy)4]+ was directly compared to that of [BnNMe3]+ in 1 M NaOD/CD3OD. The high base stability of [P(N(Me)Cy)4]+ relative to [BnNMe3]+ inspired the prepn. of AAEM materials composed of phosphonium units attached to polyethylene. The AAEMs (hydroxide cond. of 22 Â± 1 mS cm-1 at 22 Â°C) were prepd. using ring-opening metathesis polymn., and their stabilities were evaluated in 15 M KOH at 22 Â°C and in 1 M KOH at 80 Â°C.

An anion exchange membrane (AEM) was prepd. from comb-shaped copolymers bearing locally and densely functionalized side chains. In this study, we synthesized the graft copolymer of bromomethylated poly(phenylene oxide)-graft-quaternary ammonium functionalized 4-vinylbenzyl chloride (BPPO-g-QVBC), using an activator regenerated by electron transfer for atom transfer radical polymn. (ARGET ATRP) of QVBC from a BPPO macroinitiator. The BPPO-g-QVBC graft copolymers with a combination of a high graft d. and appropriate graft length present advanced materials for AEMs. Flexible and transparent membranes were obtained by casting the polymers from NMP solns., and displayed a microphase-sepd. morphol. with nano-sized ionic clusters embedded in the hydrophobic BPPO matrix. Accordingly, the resultant membranes show considerably high conductivities, up to 0.1 S cm-1 at 80 Â°C, derived from the special polymer architecture. This study gives some pioneering insights and directions from the viewpoint of macromol. design to prep. highly conductive AEMs.

To overcome alkali-resistant and synthetic hurdles to alk. anion-exchange membranes (AAEMs) for alk. fuel cells, the polyacylation of pre-quaternized monomers as a straightforward and versatile approach has been proposed for the first time. Via this approach, novel arom. anion-exchange polyelectrolytes featuring a long pendent spacer (i.e., -O-(CH2)4-) instead of a conventional benzyl-type spacer (i.e., -CH2-) are successfully synthesized, and exhibit not only high OH- and CO32- cond. (91 mS cm-1 and 51 mS cm-1 at 60 Â°C, resp.) but also outstanding alk. stability (e.g., no degrdn. of ammonium groups after aging in 6 mol dm-3 NaOH at 60 Â°C for 40 days). Using this kind of AAEM, a promising peak power d. of 120 mW cm-2 is obtained on a preliminary H2/O2 single cell at 50 Â°C. This powerful synthetic approach together with exceptional membrane properties should pave the way to the practical application of this kind of AAEMs in alk. fuel cells.

Two-dimensional NMR spectroscopy reveals cation-triggered backbone degradation in polysulfone-based anion exchange membranes
Arges, Christopher G.; Ramani, Vijay
Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
(
2013
),
110
(
7

2490-2495, S2490/1-S2490/19

0027-8424

National Academy of Sciences

Anion exchange membranes (AEMs) find widespread applications as an electrolyte and/or electrode binder in fuel cells, electrodialysis stacks, flow and metal-air batteries, and electrolyzers. AEMs exhibit poor stability in alk. media; their degrdn. is induced by the hydroxide ion, a potent nucleophile. We have used 2D NMR techniques to investigate polymer backbone stability (as opposed to cation stability) of the AEM in alk. media. We report the mechanism behind a peculiar, often-obsd. phenomenon, wherein a demonstrably stable polysulfone backbone degrades rapidly in alk. solns. upon derivatization with alk. stable fixed cation groups. Using COSY and heteronuclear multiple quantum correlation spectroscopy (2D NMR), we unequivocally demonstrate that the added cation group triggers degrdn. of the polymer backbone in alk. via quaternary carbon hydrolysis and ether hydrolysis, leading to rapid failure. This finding challenges the existing perception that having a stable cation moiety is sufficient to yield a stable AEM and emphasizes the importance of the often ignored issue of backbone stability.

The backbone stability of benzyltrimethylammonium-functionalized polyaroms. was investigated in two structurally differing polymer architectures; quaternized poly(arylene ether) (PAE) and poly(phenylene) (PP). FTIR anal. indicated the cleavage of aryl-ether linkages in quaternized PAEs under high pH environments, while no backbone degrdn. in quaternized poly(phenylene) was obsd. The backbone degrdn. of PAEs not only significantly reduced the mech. properties of the membranes, but also neg. impacted hydroxide cond. Membrane electrode assemblies using both PAE and poly(phenylene) membranes showed good initial alk. membrane fuel cell performance. However, the PAE membrane electrode assembly displayed larger performance losses and failure after only 55 h, due to a mech. breach. No catastrophic failure of the poly(phenylene) membrane electrode assembly occurred after 300 h, which further confirmed the stability of the polymer backbone.

Anion exchange membranes are an important component in alk. electrochem. energy conversion and storage devices, and their alk. stability plays a crucial role for the long-term use of these devices. Herein, a systematic study was conducted for the anal. of polymer backbone chem. stability in alk. media. Nine representative polymer structures including poly(arylene ether)s, poly(biphenyl alkylene)s, and polystyrene block copolymers were studied for their alk. stability. Polymers with aryl ether bonds in their repeating unit showed poor chem. stability when treated with KOH and NaOCH3 solns., whereas polymers without aryl ether bonds [e.g., poly(biphenyl alkylene)s and polystyrene block copolymers] remained stable. Addnl. NMR studies and d. functional theory (DFT) calcns. of small mol. model compds. that mimic the chem. structures of poly(arylene ether)s confirmed that electron-withdrawing groups near to the aryl ether bonds in the repeating unit accelerate chem. degrdn. Results from this study suggest that the use of all-carbon-based polymer repeating units (i.e., polymers not bearing aryl ether bonds) can enhance long-term alk. stability of anion exchange membranes in electrochem. energy devices.

Pan, Jing; Chen, Chen; Li, Yao; Wang, Lei; Tan, Lisheng; Li, Guangwei; Tang, Xun; Xiao, Li; Lu, Juntao; Zhuang, Lin
Energy & Environmental Science
(

Alk. polymer electrolytes (APEs) are an emerging material that enables the use of nonprecious-metal catalysts in electrochem. energy technol., such as fuel cell and water electrolysis. Yet the OH- conduction in APE has been of much lower efficiency than the H+ conduction in its acidic counterpart (typically Nafion), leading to a large dissipative loss in energy conversion applications. Here we report that, by properly constructing ion-aggregating structures in APE, a OH- conducting highway can be built, such that the OH- conduction in APE becomes as efficient as the H+ conduction in Nafion (greater than 0.1 S cm-1 at 80 Â°C under moderate ion-exchange capacity 1.0 mmol g-1). The optimal approach to constructing such an ionic highway is first screened computationally using coarse-grained mol. dynamics (CGMD) simulations, and then implemented exptl. based on a quaternary ammonia polysulfone (QAPS) model system. The resulting ordered structure of ion assembly has been unambiguously revealed by both the theor. calcd. structure factor and exptl. results of TEM and SAXS. These findings have not only furthered our understanding about the ionic channels in APE, but also provided a general strategy for the rational design of polymer electrolytes.

Improving long-term cation stability is crucial for adopting anion exchange membrane fuel cells as a com. viable technol. in clean energy conversion applications. To reliably identify the most stable cation structures, the authors analyzed the cation stability of various synthetically prepd. quaternary ammonium org. mols. via a Ag oxide ion exchange reaction. This method enabled one to compare the stability of various structures of quaternary ammonium hydroxide in pure form in H2O without excess alk. soln. or inconsistencies faced in the presence of polymer backbones. By quant. comparing cation degrdn. via NMR, the authors were able to identify three cation structures with greater cation stability than the most known benzyltrimethylammonium. The authors were able to elucidate byproduct formation and degrdn. mechanisms as a result of hydroxide attack. Alkyl-substituted cations seem to impart greater stability than benzylic-substituted cations in the presence of hydroxide anions in aq. soln.

Stable Elastomeric Anion Exchange Membranes Based on Quaternary Ammonium-Tethered Polystyrene-b-poly(ethylene-co-butylene)-b-polystyrene Triblock Copolymers
Mohanty, Angela D.; Ryu, Chang Y.; Kim, Yu Seung; Bae, Chulsung

A chem. stable and elastomeric triblock copolymer, polystyrene-b-poly(ethylene-co-butylene)-b-polystyrene (SEBS), was functionalized with various benzyl- and alkyl-substituted quaternary ammonium (QA) groups for anion exchange membrane (AEM) fuel cell applications. Synthetic methods involving transition metal-catalyzed C-H borylation and Suzuki coupling were utilized to incorporate six different QA structures to the polystyrene units of SEBS. Changes in AEM properties as a result of different QA moieties and chem. stability under alk. conditions were investigated. Anion exchange polymers bearing the trimethylammonium pendants, the smallest QA cation moiety, exhibited the most significant changes in water uptake and block copolymer domain spacing to offer the best ion transport properties. It was demonstrated that incorporating stable cation structures to a polymer backbone comprising solely C-H and C-C bonds resulted in AEM materials with improved long-term alk. stability. After 4 wk in 1 M NaOH at 60 and 80 Â°C, SEBS-QA AEMs remained chem. stable. Fuel cell tests using benzyltrimethylammonium-contg. SEBS (SEBS-TMA) as an AEM demonstrated excellent performance, generating one of the best max. power d. values and lowest ohmic resistance with low Pt catalyst loaded electrode reported thus far. Both polymer backbone and cation functional group remained stable after 110 h lifetime test at 60 Â°C.

A new bisphenol monomer, 9,9-bis(3,5-dimethoxy-4-hydroxyphenyl) fluorene, was synthesized and polymd. to form fluorene-based poly(arylene ether sulfone) copolymers contg. tetra-methoxy groups (MPAES). After converting the methoxy group to the reactive hydroxyl group, the resp. side-chain type sulfonated copolymers (SPAES) were obtained by sulfobutylation. The polymers were characterized by 1H NMR, thermogravimetric anal. (TGA), water uptake, and proton and methanol transport for fuel cell applications. These SPAES copolymers had good overall properties as polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) materials, having high proton cond. in the range of 0.061-0.209 and 0.146-0.365 S/cm at 30 and 80Â° (under hydrated conditions), resp. SPAES-39 (IEC = 1.93 mequiv/g) showed higher or comparable proton cond. than that of Nafion 117 at 50-95% RH (relative humidity). The methanol permeabilities of these membranes were in the range of 3.22 to 13.1 Ã 10-7 cm2/s, which is lower than Nafion (15.5 Ã 10-7 cm2/s). In comparison with some reported sulfonated poly(arylene ether sulfone)s contg. pendent sulfophenyl groups, the present fluorene-based SPAES contg. clustered flexible pendent aliph. sulfonic acid groups displayed better properties, such as lower water uptake and higher proton conductivities. A combination of high proton conductivities, low water uptake, and low methanol permeabilities for selected SPAES indicates that they are good candidate proton exchange membrane materials for evaluation in fuel cell applications.

Highly sulfonated poly(ether sulfone)s with densely populated flexible acid side chains were prepd. for fuel cell applications by polycondensation of 3,3'-dihydroxybenzidine with bis(4-fluorophenyl)sulfone and 4,4'-biphenol, followed by postsulfonation using 1,4-butanesultone at room temp. The sulfonated polymers gave tough, flexible, and transparent membranes by solvent casting. The membranes had high ion exchange capacity (IEC) values (2.47-2.95 mequiv/g) and displayed good proton conductivities in the range of 13.90-20.90Ã10-2 and 1.08-2.21Ã10-2 S/cm at 95% and 35% relative humidity (RH) (80Â°), resp. In particular, the S-PES-55 membrane with the highest IEC value showed higher or comparable proton cond. than that of Nafion 212 in the range of 35-95% RH. The morphologies of these membranes were investigated by TEM anal., which exhibited well-connected hydrophilic channels due to their high IEC values and densely populated flexible acid side chains. In contrast with many reported highly sulfonated polymers, the membranes showed good dimensional stability regardless of their high IEC values.

Three sulfonated arom. polymers with different sequence lengths were studied to better understand the relation between mol. structure, morphol., and properties of proton exchange membranes as a function of relative humidity. A random copolymer with a statistical distribution of sulfonic acid groups had small domain size, whereas an alternating polymer with sulfonic acid groups spaced evenly along the polymer chain was found to have larger, but quite isolated, domains. The multiblock copolymer studied showed highly phase-sepd. hydrophilic and hydrophobic domains, with good long-range connectivity. Scanning force microscopy as a function of relative humidity was used to observe water absorption and swelling of the hydrophilic domains in each of the three membranes. The cond., water sorption kinetics, and fuel cell performance, esp. at low relative humidity, were highly dependent upon the morphol. The multiblock copolymer outperformed both the random and alternating systems at 100Â° and 40% RH fuel cell operating conditions and showed similar performance to Nafion.

Exploring Different Cationic Alkyl Side Chain Designs for Enhanced Alkaline Stability and Hydroxide Ion Conductivity of Anion-Exchange Membranes
Dang, Hai-Son; Jannasch, Patric
Macromolecules (Washington, DC, United States)

In order to systematically improve the performance of anion-exchange membranes (AEMs) for alk. fuel cells, a series of poly(phenylene oxide)s (PPOs) was tethered with cationic alkyl side chains of different lengths and configurations. PPO was first functionalized with bromomethyl and longer bromoalkyl side chains, resp., before introducing quaternary ammonium (QA) groups via Menshutkin reactions involving trimethylamine and dimethyloctylamine, resp. This resulted in samples with QA groups attached to PPO either directly in benzylic positions, or via flexible pentyl and heptyl spacer units, resp. In addn., the polymers were configured with or without octyl extender chains pendant to the QA groups. All the cationic PPOs had an excellent soly. in, e.g., methanol and DMSO, and flexible and mech. robust AEMs with an ion exchange capacity of â¼1.4 mequiv g-1 were cast from soln. Anal. by small-angle X-ray scattering showed that the flexible spacer units greatly facilitated efficient ionic phase sepn., regardless of the presence of the extender chain. These AEMs reach very high OH- conductivities, exceeding 0.1 S cm-1 at 80 Â°C. A clear optimum cond. was obsd. for the AEMs with pentyl spacers. Despite a markedly lower water uptake, AEMs configured with addnl. extender chains still reached a high cond., 0.07 S cm-1 at 80 Â°C. Importantly, the spacer units induced a high alk. stability and no degrdn. of these AEMs was detected after storage in 1 M NaOH at 80 Â°C during 8 days. In comparison, the benchmark materials with QA groups placed in conventional benzylic positions severely degraded under the same conditions. The findings demonstrated that AEMs suitable for fuel cell applications can be achieved by tuning the configuration of flexible cationic alkyl side chains to reach an excellent combination of ionic phase sepn., chem. stability, water uptake, and OH- cond.

A reliable and practical approach is offered for the two crit. fundamental challenges that remain in step-growth polymn.: synthesis of narrow polydispersity and ultrahigh mol. wt. polymers. The polymers are obtained by superacid catalyzed polyhydroxyalkylation involving two consecutive steps - slow and fast. Polymer syntheses with decrease in reactivity of intermediates lead to narrow polydispersity polymers, while nonstoichiometric reactions result in polymers of high and ultrahigh mol. wt. Linear arom. polymers with ultra high mol. wt. Mn > 1 000 000 and narrow polydispersity (Mw/Mn = 1.15-1.16) have been obtained. An unusual step-selective mechanism is suggested for the formation of these polymers.
